Journal Story: I first caught the AT thru-hiking "bug" back in 1999 when I co-led a youth trip on the AT. We hiked the last 50 miles or so over 5 days, ending at Mt. Katahdin. Our leaders were former thru-hikers themselves and planned this trip as a fun and meaningful experience for the five teens who were in our charge. We met a few thru-hikers and they seemed to us like a rare but friendly breed in themselves. They happily relieved us of any spare food we had, it being the last half of the 100 mile wilderness and all. My 14 year old son was one of the youth on this trip. I know it made a big impression on him, because he thru-hiked in 2010. His stories combined with my own impressions from the youth trip planted the seed, and so here I am, about to embark on my own adventure of a lifetime.

Little snow storm (Niko) came through New England today and my employer canceled work due to the weather, so I used the time between shoveling sessions to go through my gear again and figure out how to fit everything into my pack. I had taken a class at REI on AT thru-hike preparation, and the instructor said you should buy your backpack last (after you have all your gear that needs to go in it), but most people make the backpack the first purchase. That was true for me too. I have a Gregory Baltoro 65 and somehow I'll have to make it work. Just a little over a month before I leave for Georgia. Getting excited and hoping I'll be ready for this.

I want to thank my family, and most importantly, my wife, for supporting my crazy dream. We have talked about it (thru-hiking the AT) over the past couple years and by now I think she knows how important this is to me. Thanks Darlin'. I owe you big time. I also want to thank my co-workers who are picking up the slack during my 6 month leave of absence. I realize I am creating somewhat of a hardship since it's such a small department, and just hope you'll have me back when I'm done.

So with a couple pretty major snow storms coming through New England in the last few days, I have been getting some exercise by shoveling snow. Not sure how that will translate to hiking exactly but it all good cardio, right?I also got to do a little cross country skiing which I missed last year because it was kind of a bust snow-wise. In the last outing I managed to irritate the skin on my heel, and got to practice good foot care afterwards by applying moleskin on it. I also went shopping for typical groceries so I could gauge the weight vs. calorie content. I hope this is not boring anyone but soon enough I should be able to write about ACTUALLY hiking, places and people, etc.

With less than two weeks to go before departure, this thru-hike attempt is beginning to feel very real. I booked my flight to Atlanta today, and expect to be on the approach trail on or about March 13th. I say attempt because I know the odds of making it all the way to Maine are not in my favor. But I'll take it one day at a time and do my best to hang in there. My hope is that the hiker community I am about to become part of will help sustain my drive to continue.

With only one week before departure, I am getting quite anxious to begin the journey, and so focused on wrapping up loose ends at work in the best way possible, check and re-check me gear, etc. So focused in fact that I was completely taken by surprise when my family threw a birthday/ bon-voyage party for me on Saturday. It was so wonderful to see all the family, friends and neighbors who came to wish me well, I felt like I could float through the first days and weeks of the trail without my feet ever touching ground. Thanks to all who came and even those who could not (I admit that answering all the questions about gear, food, snakes, bears, etc. was a bit exhausting).I will hold all of your well wishes close as I'm sure I will need them from time to time.

I'm sitting at a friends house in Atlanta, getting ready for my ride to the trail tomorrow morning. Excited and a little nervous but my friend is a former thru-hiker and he has given me the encouragement I need.

Gaps and Knobs
First off, most if not all of what I plan to write about is not for my fellow thruhikers; they know all too well of this Experience we share. No, my intended readership is family and friends, on whom I hope to impart some understanding of the day to day. And also for me of course, to have something to look back on. Although I am now in Franklin,North Carolina, my recollection of a lot of the Georgia hiking was a series of gaps and knobs. Georgia, and for all I know, most of the AT, is like this. As the trail winds through the hills, at some points there are creases in the landscape known as gaps. Some of these have paved roads, others have unpaved Forest service roads, and still others are deep in the woods. The nice thing or bad thing depending on your hiking preferences is that the trail leading into gaps is downhill, which of course means the trail leading out is uphill. Some gaps are frequented by Trail angels ( more on that later). The knobs are often good places to get a good view of the area, at least in nice weather. So on a daily basis I might go thru several gaps and knobs on my journey. Gaps are good places to drink water, eat a candy bar, etc. to provide energy for the upcoming climb. Knobs are where at least for me, I need to stretch before beginning my descent in order to prevent knee injury. 
So yeah, gaps and knobs.

What a night on the top of Tray Mountain. A true thunderstorm raged across the mountain for what seemed like hours. My tent did well considering I fell on it when I got out at one point. The tent poles bent a little but I think they will be okay.

This post is for my new friend Pat from Houston (Trail name Howdy) who I met a few days ago at Neels Gap while Trail magic was being bestowed on us. He must have seen I was hiking alone and he asked me if I wanted to share a cabin that he had reserved for the night to save on the cost. I hesitated and asked him to let me think about my options but the Hiker Hostel was full and I was not planning to hike any more that day so really the options were limited. My hesitation may have been partly cost driven ( I had just stayed two nights in a hotel in Dahlonega waiting out the cold weather) and partly the fact that this was a complete stranger, but then again we generally all were strangers. I hemmed and hawed. He said "look man, you are over thinking it" and I realized he was right. For those who know me, that pretty much sums up how I deal with a lot of decisions!
Pat said he was just hiking a small section of the AT to check out his gear in preparation for a scouting event later this year as well as an eventual thru hike. We hiked and camped together for the next few days and he decided to head home today. I really enjoyed hiking with you Pat and valued your good advice about everything hiking related. I wish you all the best. If you are ever in the Boston area look me up (after September).

Hey all. I'm staying tonight and tomorrow night in Franklin, NC to resupply and rest. I plan to backfill some of the entries with more details but so far have been busy just figuring things out. I'll change the name of posts based on the topic, othwise if they just have a date there will be no more information.Peace,FoggyP.S. I'll be breakfasting tomorrow at the Baptist church which runs a free Hiker breakfast every day for several weeks. How cool is that?

Another beautiful day on the AT in Noth Carolina, although it was warm and I managed to develop heel blisters on both feet. I'm taking a zero day tomorrow to. Rest, resupply and take care of my feet. Planning to get back out there on Tuesday. Hi to all back home .

Hi all,So I've been in Fontana Village since Tuesday and getting quite restless to get back on the trail. The weather the past couple days has been very stormy and it seemed wise to stay out rather than pushing. Also I have developed some heel blisters which need time to get get better. With any luck I'll be able to make some miles again starting tomorrow.
Good to be back in trail again.
MUD is the theme for today. From melting snow and lots of hikers. Also the trail is worn so the water collects right where we are walking.
I am in the hiking bubble I assume since there are so many hikers on the ail and at shelters. Passed a Ridge Runner around 2:00 who said he estimated 45 hikers northbound so far today.
Hike today in beautiful weather included Clingmans Dome
Spent the day on Gatlinburg at Owain's apt.
Lunch at Charlie's Bunion
Best day yet with trail magic twice and sleeping under the stars
Clouds and rain today

Hiked out of Hot Springs alone this morning as others were going out for breakfast. Jerry (Kitchen Sink) decided to go home today. His feet are bothering him. He says he has no regrets. Cloudy then light rain.
Tough hiking day today due to muddy conditions followed by roots and rocks. Last mile before Licklog Gap was very challenging with hard scramble over rocks for what seemed like a long distance.

A good day of hiking today. Made 14.0 miles. Had a close encounter with a "large" animal last night that could be heard in the area walking around slowly. Person in a tent next to me made the situation more tense by saying he was carrying a gun and would shoot it if it got any closer. He thought it was very close to our tents but I think it was more like 50 feet away.
Hiked in muddy conditions due to rain in the afternoon.
Zero day to rest and resupply and stay out of the rain
Clouds and fog all day. Saw nobody all day which is.bit strange.Camped near decorated tree dedicated to Max Norrell.
A routine hike today but wnded in a pleasant fireside conversation with fellow they hikers.
One of the best days yet with amazing views. A strenuous day with miles and elevation.
A challenging day even though shorter than usual with the climbing of Little and Big Hump Mountains in high winds before descending into the gap at US 19E.

A nice warm day, left camp around 7:15 and hiked 16.0 miles today.  Varying terrain including stream, waterfalls, rock gorges, lake views and dam.  Didn't know it at the time but I must have strained a muscle in my right ankle today because the next couple days of hiking were painful.

Today was the longest hiking day so far, which is unfortunate because of my muscle strain.  I was almost out of food and had no fuel so it made sense to push for Damascus.  The trail was easy and my pack was light so I made it in about 8 hours of almost non-stop hiking.

Our dear friend Meg has asked some questions about the thru hiking experience. One has to do with the interaction with other hikers. I think for most, thru hiking is a solitary experience. There are certainly exceptions, for example I have met father/daughter pairs, one father/son pair, couples, siblings, and friends who have come to hike the trail together. Some who have met on the trail have decided to hike together at least for a stretch, for various reasons. One good reason which I have taken advantage of is sharing a room to save money when staying in a trail town. At shelters, campsites and trail towns which need to be visited in order to get food and other supplies, I often see the same people at least for a week or two. Conversations usually include topics like gear, food, trail conditions, aches and pains, or what ever happened to so and so. Deeper discussions are rare since I never really know if I will see this person again.
Hiked out alone on a nice day which included some walking along or next to the Virginia Creeper Trail ( now a bike path).  Rain started as soon as tent was set up.  Good timing.

Day started off cloudy and not too cold but got very windy, colder and snowed by afternoon.  Very tough hiking.  Stayed in top floor of shelter.  Too cold to fix dinner.  Woke up with almonds in my shoe.
Beautiful day, started off chilly but warmed up.
rain overnight and a very rainy hike to the visitor center. Got a shuttle to Marion for resupply and to spend the night.  Had dinner with Pat from St. Louis.  Trail name Persistent.

today started off ok with just light rain.  Had lunch at Chestnut Knob Shelter.  Rained hard all afternoon though with some lightning.  Last 6 miles seemed to take forever.  Called a shuttle for a ride to Bland to stay in a motel tonight.
late start.waiting for shuttle driver.  Got back to trail head around noon.hiked to mile 588.8.  Nice sunny day and easy trail.
got off to a good start from trailside campsite, great weather but aggravated ankle injury from earlier this month.  We stopped at Trent's Grocery for cheeseburger and fries.  Tented nearby.
walked 0.5 back to trailhead from Trent's and then to Docs Knob.  Long hike but ankle doing ok with wrap.
hiked into Pearisburg today with nice views of town from the Ledges above..  staying at Plaza Motel and sharing a room with Persistent.
took a zero day at Pearisburg to rest, etc.
hiked out of Pearisburg and ended at shelter.  Longer hike than we wanted but water was scarce on this section.
Hiked 12.7 to War Spur Shelter. Stayed in shelter.

Hiked from war Spur shelter mile667.4 to Sarver Hollow shelter mile 679.6, total of 12.2 miles. Day started off nice, warm and sunny but by 3:00 a thunderstorm came through and soaked Pat and I. We decided to take shelter at this location instead of hiking further.

Hiked 16.1 to Pickle Branch shelter. Tough hike and got lightheaded a few times. Could be meds, dehydration, over exerting or diet. Rain started just before we got here. Feeling low overall with everything wet and not eating enough I guess.
Hiked 6.7 over Dragons Tooth into Catawba Grocery on VA 624, mile 702.4. A physical climb and even more challenging descent from the top.
taking. Zero day to get out of the rain and rest, resupply, etc.
taking.another zero day today.  Got to see the town a bit and enjoy restaurant food instead of trail food.
today's hike included fording  a stream, climb up to McAfee Knob.good day and weather allowed for decent photos from the knob.

briefly glimpsed a bear this morning running across the trail ahead of us..  we crossed several power lines, a river, a railroad, and Tinker Cliffs were really great with a strong breeze blowing up from the valley to keep us from feeling like we would be blown off the cliffs.

We passed the 1/3 mileage this morning at 730.1.  Pat had to turn back shortly thereafter with hip pain.  He suggested I go on alone as he was going to seek medical attention.  Remaining hike was a bit lonely feeling, but there was trail magic on the Blue Ridge thanks to the parents of Wes from Worcester. Total miles today 18.5

Relatively easy hike today, still running along Blue Ridge Parkway for first part of day.  Got to trailhead around 11:30 and called a shuttle to Middle Creek Campground.  Picked up my food that had been forwarded from Daleville.
Big climb today , felt more like 20 miles.
ATough downhill today but we crossed the longest footbridge on the AT.  Hitched a ride into Glasgow for food and free tenting in town park.
hitched a ride back to trailhead. A strenuous hike today out of the gap.
Big climb today but all is well.
another big hiking day including Priest Mountain and then a big downhill to Tye River where we cooked dinner and I was able to rinse off in the river.
A shorter hike today and then a ride to the Devils Backbone Brewery which offers free camping.  Stayed overnight after enjoying some beer and good food.
A long hike today to reach the trailhead for a ride into Waynesboro.
took a zero day for resupply and other chores.
We got a ride out of Waynesboro from Trail Angel Cindy to US 250, and hiked on a beautiful day to mile 878.1.  The trail was easy but still ended the day sore and tired.  In bed by 7:45.

Today's hike got off to an early start (7:00) and by early afternoon we had hiked over 10 miles on easy terrain, crossing the Skyline Drive several times. The highest point may have been Blackrock. We stopped at the Loft Mountain Camp store and I got an orange juice and pastry. Then hiked another mile or so to the Loft Mountain Wayside for a cheeseburger fries and chocolate shake. They were overpriced but very good.Hiked to mile 894.9 and found good stealth camping site. 16.8 miles. Chilidawg , Persistent and Barrel.
18.9 miles today of up and down terrain and several road crossings. Also reached mile 900. Chilidawg provides trail magic of coke and fries chicken. Camping off trail at mile 913.8.

An easier day today, including coffee, juice and muffin at Lewis Campground store, then lunch and camping at Big Meadow Campground. 11.0 miles on a beautiful sunny day.

We met two unsuspecting trail angels when we arrived at Big Meadows Campground. Big Meadows is located on Skyline Drive and has many RV sites as well as tenting sites, and the AT is directly adjacent to it. Four of us were renting a site for the night since it was so convenient. After we setup our tents, we introduced ourselves to Suzanne and her daughter Meg from D.C. who were camping for a couple of days with their two dogs. Since the camp store and Wayside were almost a mile away, we asked Suzanne if it might be possible to get a ride there and back. She not only obliged us but also offered to give us another ride in the morning. She also offered hotdogs which we gladly accepted. The biggest gift was the kindness and genuine interest she showed in our individual and collective AT stories. Thank you Suzanne!
zero day today for the usual resupply, rest, etc.  the temperature in town is 100 so I am glad not to be hiking anyway.  The motel has a pool which was refreshing.

With some grumbling about our heavy packs due to resupply of 3 to 4 days of food, we shouldered them anyway, said goodbye to the comforts of the motel, pool and nearby eateries and resumed our northward journey . It's a warm day today but not nearly as hot as yesterday which topped out at 100 in Front Royal. Persistent's sister Elizabeth gave us a ride back to the trail.

Shelter where lunch was enjoyed. This one has a spring fed shower, gazebo with picnic table and horseshoe pit in addition to what is shown.
Hiked 15.2 miles to Dicks Dome Shelter area where we found some rocky ground for tenting.

After camping at a rocky tent site last night, we were eager to get out of there and be on our way. Today's milestone is mile 1,000, and to get there we have to hike through several miles of the Roller Coaster, so named because of a series of tightly packed ascents and descents. We are also looking to get to Bears Den Hostel for food, showers and camping or a bunk.
The Roller Coaster.
Total miles today was 18.3.

After a pleasant evening and overnight in my tent in the backyard of the hostel, I had pancakes for breakfast and got back on the trail on a misty morning. The Hostel owners were very pleasant and friendly.
the trail was easy in terms of grade, but had many areas which were very rocky, making it more difficult. Total miles today 19.6 to get into Town.
hiking today included a two hour break under a tarp waiting out a thunderstorm.
I got a chance to meet my nephew from DC for dinner today.  It was great to see him again.
enjoyed trail magic for dinner and breakfast provided by a crew that has been doing this for a week every year for 14 years.

After a nice breakfast provided by the trail angels Cook Doctor and staff at Caledonia State Park, we made it past the official halfway mark today at mile 1,094.9. We are camping at Toms Run Shelter. Thunder in the area this evening and it is very warm and humid.
I did not attempt the half gallon challenge offered at Pine Grove Furnace State Park, settled for a pint instead.

After a hike of about 15 miles in rocky terrain we arrived in Port Clinton in a downpour where the trail comes out to the Reading and Northern Railroad yard.  Got a ride from Steve to Hamburg where we stayed at the Microtel and enjoyed dinner and drinks at Pappy T's.

After checking out of motel and doing errands including lunch at Cabellas, we got a ride from Hamburg back to Port Clinton around 3:30 pm.  We stopped at the Prot Clinton Fire Company and had some beers and pizza.  Camped overnight at the Pavilion.
long hike today and then a trip to McDonalds in Dopplers truck, fireworks viewed from Bake Oven Knob.
We spent most of the afternoon and evening at Detzi's Tavern, and camped in a field behind the Tavern.
We stopped at the lake for pizza and then hiked up to the High Point monument.

we had a wonderful visit from my Mom, sister Michelle, Aunt Marge and cousin Kevin, at the Deer Head Inn where we stayed, complete with enough food to feed a small army.  I meant to update my journal but got side tracked completely

left at noon or so and got an ice cream on the way out of town.  Within a mile I was crossing into NJ from PA. There were a lot of day hikers and groups using the Travis and the river for recreation.  It was a perfect weather day.
we found trail magic from the Hunterton Hiking Club in the morning and I had a hot dog, a soda and a beer at 8:30 am.  The Fire tower was a cool place to camp.
today's hike included a noon to 4:30 stop at Wit's End Tavern in Unionville for a burger and beer.

A very hot and humid day, which was made easier by an ice cream stop at Heaven Hill Farm, then hot dogs by Mitch and finally tail magic.  Then we had to climb the "Stairway to Heaven" during which we got caught in a thunderstorm which turned the trail into a river.

today's hike started late at about 11:30 to let the overnight rain clear out.  It turned out the rain started up again at about noon anyway.  The hiking was very challenging due to the exposed Ledges which were slippery and steep.  Thankfully we had planned to get to town after a hike of only. 8 miles or so.
Taking a zero day today to rest and resupply.

We hiked out of Greenwood Lake NY this morning after breakfast at the Morning Buzz. Hiked 11.0 miles not counting the 1 mile side trail back to the AT. The terrain was challenging at times and we decided to camp at Little Dam Lake, mile 1381.0
today's hike was mostly uneventful and ended with a partial view of the NYC skyline from the shelter.  I arrived and set up my tent just ahead of a thunderstorm.
today's weather was very hot and humid but the free camping at Graymoor included a (cold) shower which was most welcome.  We walked a mile or so to a sports bar for dinner.

at the end of today's hike there was a state park with concession stand which was closing warly when I got there because of a concern for the water quality in the lake.  We did not get to go swimming as hoped but met some folks working for the state on invasive species control and they invited us to join them at their campsite for refreshments and conversation.
today's hiking included a break for sandwich and drinks at a deli on Rte 52.

I passed by the Appalachian Trail RR station and enjoyed a mid day break before hiking at night to the shelter.  My left has started hurting and I hope I can continue this journey without needing time off.  I think I've been overdoing it these last few days.

I walked into Connecticut today and entered New England finally.  The highlight was at the end of the day when my sister and her husband met us at the trailhead in Kent, CT to help us get around town for laundry, grocery run and dinner.  Many thanks to my Aunt Marge who graciously offered to pick up the tab for dinner even though she was not here.
lots of ups and downs today plus a long stretch of level ground along the rover bank.

I enjoyed a day off from hiking in Cornwall.  Stayed at the Hitching Post Motel for two nights and relaxed.  George  Gibb picked us up and we drove to Sharon for dinner at When Pigs Fly South Barbecue.

I admit I have not been taking detailed notes for each day, but as I recall this was a relatively easy hike today.  When I arrived in Falls Village, a few hiker friends were sitting outside the local package store.  I joined them and we enjoyed some cold beer and laughs including trying to guess what patrons of the store were going to purchase.  We camped at the Toymakers Café in their yard.  The café was not open the next day however so breakfast was from my food bag.
Hiking with Persistent, Barrel, and Chilidawg these days.  We passed the 1,500 mile mark, and had a nice lunch break in Salisbury, CT for a couple hours.

Today we said so long to Connecticut and entered Massachusetts.  When we arrived at Rte 7, Trail Angel Joe was there and gave us a ride into Great Barrington, where we could camp for free behind the Community Center.  We ate McDonald's like it was going out of style, and then went to the bowling alley to drink a couple draft beers and watch the baseball game on TV.

We got picked up by Carolee at the trail head around noon, She also brought goodies which we ate on the spot and were able to feed a few fellow thru hikers as well.  Barrel had friends with a "camp" on Lake Buel nearby where we spent the night of the 28th, all the next day and night.  A wonderful time was had by all, with special thanks to our hosts Don and Kyle, and their grand daughter Jane.  We ate and lounged, went for a swim in the lake, and rested.
a perfect day for relaxing by the lake and enjoying the company of friends and loved ones.

After another delicious meal (breakfast burritos and Mimosas), we said fond good byes to Don, Kyle and Jane and headed back to the trail.  Carolee once again played Trail Angel and gave out the remaining goodies to hikers as they passed by.  She even gave a ride to a hiker with a lame dog.
Today's hike included crossing I-90 and Rte 20.

We hiked through Dalton, MA today and enjoyed food and beer at Jacobs Restaurant before hiking several more miles to the campsite for the night.  Gene Morgan, a patron at Jacobs, told us he is 88 years old and just got his drivers license renewed. He also told us that the paper for US currency is made in Dalton.  The weather has been very nice if a bit warm.
We climbed Mt. Greylock today under cloudy skies.  The climb was not as difficult as I thought it would be, given the 2,500 ft. elevation gain.

Climbing down the rest of the way from Mt. Greylock, we entered North Adams, MA and walked a half mile to Stop and Shop for refreshments before resuming our hike.  We also crossed into Vermont in the afternoon.

A difficult descent down to VT 9, but was rewarded with the rest of today and tomorrow as time off from the trail.  We are staying at the Catamount Motel, a hiker friendly place on South Street near downtown.
We are going to 4 Corners North Homebrew Festival in Bennington this afternoon.  Good thing we are not hiking!
A perfect day for hiking.  My knee is still hurting but I have to keep on going.
Destination: Stealth site after Kid Gore shelter

Journal Story: Today was a nice cool day. A long hike on muddy trails included a climb over Stratton Mountain and then a 0.6 mile side trail to the campsite on the far side of the pond.
Start location: Stealth site after Kid Gore shelter

Journal Story: After a rainy overnight, the hike today is best described as dank, dark, muddy and really not much fun.  We got a nice view of Manchester Center from Prospect Rock.  The highlight was spending the night at the Bromley Mountain summit where the ski patrol warming hut was open and available for hikers to stay in.  We got a great view of the sunset from there.

Today was sunny and cool, a great day to be hiking, except for the last 2 miles or so which caught us in a sudden downpour that drenched everything in sight including a bunch of day hikers who were not expecting rain.  Baker Peak was fun at midday.

Today was a nice day, no issues to speak of.  Got. Nice view of Rutland Airport from the trail.  We hiked to VT103 where Carolee picked us up and took us to dinner (Applebee's) and then ice cream (Ben & Jerry's) before returning us to the trail so we could hike the last mile or so to the shelter.

The hike today included a big climb over Killington Mountain.  We stopped at the top for lunch at the summit restaurant, which was nice but pricey.  Carolee picked us up again at the end of the day and after dinner in Rutland, delivered Persistent to a motel in town while she I proceeded to Orwell to spend the night at her family's place.  Also, Emma surprised me at the restaurant in Rutland by popping in unexpectedly.  It was delightful to see her.

The hike today included a big climb over Killington Mountain.  We stopped at the top for lunch at the summit restaurant, which was nice but pricey.  Carolee picked us up again at the end of the day and after dinner in Rutland, delivered Persistent to a motel in town while she I proceeded to Orwell to spend the night at her family's place.  Also, Emma surprised me at the restaurant in Rutland by popping in unexpectedly.  It was delightful to see her.

Today was a zero day and included a day trip to the Addison County Fair as well as spend time with other members of the family.  We had a nice dinner put on by Kristin which helped keep me well fed for my continuing adventure.
After a ride back to the trail including a hearty breakfast with Emma at a local restaurant, we hiked to a small trailside area where there was enough room for two tents.
Small ups and downs today in terms of terrain, and including a stop at Edge of the Woods Farm stand for lunch.

After crossing VT14, we were hailed by Linda and Randy Hart, who offered breakfast on their porch, something they have been doing for who knows how long.   We hung out there awhile before resuming the days hike.  We also stopped at Dan and Whits in Norwich before having dinner at Murphy's in Hanover.  Sarah (Kristin's friend) picked us up and took us to her house for the night.  It rained hard overnight so we were especially glad to have a roof overhead.
Afyer getting dropped off by Sarah (thanks so much!), we had breakfast at Lou's and then resumed our hike.  There was trail magic (pizza and soda ) at Three Mile Rd.

we hiked a shorter than usual distance today, trying to plan out the days before hiking Moosilauke.  The weather was very nice today and provided good views from Smart Mountain and the Fire Wardens tower.

Today was a very rainy day with difficult conditions for hiking including climb over Mt Cube.  The highlight was a Trail Angel named Carl, or "the omelet guy", who makes delicious omelets as much as you want for hikers.

the big climb today over Mt. Moosilauke went well, even with rain the previous day and overnight.  Carolee picked us up at the trail and we stayed in Lincoln at the Parker Motel.  Chilidawg and Barrel rejoined the group as well, temporarily at least.
Destination: Lost River Rd, NH 112, Kinsman Notch

Journal Story: Hi all, I know it's been a couple of weeks since my last entry and I'm not sure when I'll be able to fill in the gap, but for now I just wanted to say the hike is going well and I am about to enter the Presidential Range in the next couple of days.  I'll admit the miles are taking a toll on my body But there are now less than 400 miles to go so I'm sure I'll get there.
A tough climb out of the Notch.  Today was a partial eclipse but in the woods I did not notice the change.
Start location: Lost River Rd, NH 112, Kinsman Notch

Journal Story: Climbing the Kinsmans today was very challenging but the weather was nice and we took our time.  Stopped for soup and coffee at Lonesome Lake hut.  After dropping down to US 3, we climbed again nearly to the top of Liberty to get to the campsite.

this was one of my favorite hikes, including Little Haystack, Mt Lincoln, and Mt Lafayette.  We got great views most of the day.  The terrain is more difficult than we are used to.  We were offered work for stay at the AMC hut which consisted of talking about our AT journeys to the guests staying there.
we have been lucky to have nice weather for the past few days, making the tough terrain a little easier to deal with.  We stopped for coffee and cake at Zealand Falls Hut .

Another beautiful day on the trail.  Elaine and Doug met us at Crawford Notch and drove us to a store where we could do some light resupply.  Then they hiked with us up to Webster Cliffs which was fun  and great to have the company.

today's hike included Mt. Washington but the real highlight was that Tyler and Emma met us on the trail and hiked with us up Washington.  They had camped at the trailhead for the Mt Eisenhower trail.  It was wonderful to see them and spend some time together.  We had lunch at the summit and they took the cog railway back down.  The afternoon hike was very difficult with a lot of rock hopping and scrambling.  We made it to the hut by around 7 and were told we could not stay there.  Unable to find a campsite in the area, the hut boss finally relented and allowed us to sleep on the floor. Altogether it was a day of highs and lows, literally and figuratively.

A straight up climb out of the hut area to the top of Mt Madison, then another tricky scramble down to below tree line. Even though the mileage was only 7.8 today, it felt a lot longer.  Ty and Emma were waiting for us at Pinkham Notch and took us to Gorham where we stayed.

Doug and Elaine picked us up in Gorham and after a nice breakfast at Welsh's, hiked with us up Wildcat before heading back down via one of the ski trails.  We were also joined by Lynne Walsh and her dog Wilson.  It was fun to share with them some of our experiences.  At the hut, we scrubbed pans for work.

we got an early start out of the hut with a steep climb to Carter Dome.  I had a difficult day with a lot of knee pain due to the terrain, but am doing my best to deal with it.  We returned to Gorham where we had left a box of food from the other day, and stayed at the same Motor Inn.

After a night at the Motor Lodge in Gorham, NH, Persisent and I returned to the trail around noon and made it as far as Wocket Ledge, which had just enough room for two tents and provided a nice view of the area.  It is also right at the 1,900 mile mark.  The hike started with some light rain but not enough to really make us wet.
Today's hike included some tough trail and cold, windy conditions.  We crossed from NH into ME and met Chillidawg who we had not seen on the trail for several weeks.

Mahoosuc Notch was the highlight of today's hike, approximately one mile of scrambling through a "jumbled pit of boulders" as described in the AWOL book.  It required hands and feet and two times I had to remove my pack to squeeze through narrow openings.  It took about 90 minutes to cover the mile, but it was different and fun compared to the usual trail.  After a steep and difficult descent into Grafton Notch, we made dinner and camped in the woods near the parking lot.  A park employee got upset with us when we didn't take him up on his offer to find us a shuttle to town to escape the rain that was forecast.  The reason we declined was that the shuttle ride was estimated to cost $100 or more.

A very windy and foggy climb today out of Grafton Notch and over Baldpate west peak and east peak.  We were able to make it to the road by 2:30 and avoid most of the rain that began in the afternoon.  We (Persistent, Chillidawg, Barrel and I) stayed in a cabin owned by the Pine Ellis Hostel in Andover, ME.  It was rustic but served the purpose.  We dined and resupplied at a local general store.
A rooty, rocky, muddy and slippery hike today.
Today was also rainy, gloomy and muddy.  We arrived at ME 4 without a destination for the night, but were soon picked up by the shuttle for the Farmhouse Inn which was a pleasant place stay.
A zero day in Rangeley, for resupply, laundry and rest.
A nice day with good views from Saddleback Mountain.  The downhills are becoming increasingly tough, very steep and tricky especially since my knees are really starting to give me problems.
A nice day with fairly easy trail.  I hiked with Barrel today.  Mountains included Spaulding and Sugarloaf (side trails to summits which I did not hike to).

Today's mountains included South and North Crocker.  We arrived at the trail head to find trail magic (pulled pork sandwiches, soda and beer, and home made cookies).  We got picked up by neighbors of a high school friend, Jane, who has a camp about a mile from the trail.  The neighbors, Megan, Jeff and their daughter Addie, took us to town for resupply, gave us a wonderful venison chili dinner with all the fixings, and returned us to the trail in the morning.  This kind of generosity is a big part of what makes the hiking experience so special.
A nice day, with climbs including the Horn, Bigelow west peak and Avery Peak.  It was a long day, with the final two or so miles of hiking in the dark.  We arrived at the camp around 9 pm.
A bigger mile day today, owing to the easier terrain.  My knees are really bothering me but I'm determined to keep going.
Highlights of today's trail included ferry service by canoe across the Kennebec River, and a stop at the Caratunk House B&B for resupply, pulled pork sandwich and chocolate shake.
Another gorgeous weather day, climbed Moxie Bald.

An easy hike today with flat terrain.  We got picked up at the trail head by an old friend and colleague, Cary, who had cold beer and soda for us.  He delivered us to Shaw's Hiker Hostel and joined us for dinner at the Lakeshore House.

Persistent, Chilidawg, Barrel and I all took the day off as this will be our last zero day on the trail.  We ate out, picked up our resupply boxes sent from home, and enjoyed the company of fellow thru-hikers.

Entering the 100 mile Wilderness after getting dropped off by Poet from Shaw's, my pack has about as much food as I'm willing to carry.  Luckily the terrain is relatively level for the first day.  As I approached our intended campsite for the night, I saw a sign for trail magic 0.2 miles down a dirt road.  I followed it and found a cabin which was owned by a man who's son had died some years ago.  The son was a former thru-hiker and he does this in memory of him.  He offered a hamburger and hot dog plus soda and beer.  There were several other hikers here as well but not the guys I have been hiking with.  After I ate and thanked him for his kindness, I made my way to camp to find the rest of the guys who were waiting for me.  They explained that their plan was to set up their tents and then walk back to the trail magic, which of course I didn't know until I got there.  In any case, they walked back and I went to bed.
Today's climbs included Barren Mountain, Fourth and Third Mountains.
We climbed up and down several peaks today, ending with White Cap Mountain, the last of the big mountains before the final one at Katahdin.
A big mile day due to the easier terrain and our goal of summiting Katahdin by 9/24.  The campsite was beautiful, right at the edge of Jo-Mary Lake.

Getting really close now, with Katahdin in plain view from Rainbow Ledges.  We camped at Abol Bridge Campground, right on the river.  We enjoyed dinner and breakfast with fellow hikers at the restaurant next to the camp store.  Everyone seems to be in good spirits knowing that all our hard work is nearly done.  Got supplies to get us to the end of the trail, in just two days!

A really easy day today with only 10 miles of almost level trail to get us in position for climbing Katahdin tomorrow.  I took my time, enjoying the trail and waterfalls along the way, and arrived at camp by late afternoon.  Had something to eat, took a nap, then had dinner and went to bed.

The final day of a six month and ten day journey.  The climb up Katahdin on the Hunt Trail is steep and challenging with tricky sections that require both hands and feet.  Carolee met us at Katahdin Stream Campground and relieved us of the items we won't need today, including tents, sleeping bags, etc. so our backpacks were lighter than usual.  I was excited to get to the summit, knowing that my journey will be complete today but also that my son and daughter are hiking up to join in the celebration.  They hiked up the Abol Trail and the fog near the summit made it hard to see, but I spotted them right after they saw me.  They wanted to wait until I had gone by so I could summit before them and soak in the moment.  
After a time of celebration and photos at the summit, we (Tyler, Emma, Persistent and I) hiked down via the Knife Edge and Helon Taylor Trail to Roaring Brook Campground, where Carolee was waiting for us with cold beer and warm hugs for all.
I am very grateful to all who have supported me on this trek.  Hiking the AT was a long time dream of mine and I could not have done it without you.
